    <div style="text-align: left; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold;">ITEM 2.02.&#160; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION</div>

    <div>&#160;</div>

    <div style="text-align: left; font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif; font-size: 10pt;">On October 29, 2020, Newmont Corporation, a Delaware corporation, issued a news release reporting its operating and financial results for the third quarter
      ended September 30, 2020.&#160; A copy of the news release is furnished as Exhibit 99.1 to this report.</div>

    <div>&#160;</div>

    <div><br />
    </div>

    <div style="text-align: left; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold;">ITEM 9.01.&#160; FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND EXHIBITS</div>

    <div><br />
    </div>

    <div style="text-align: left; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">(d) Exhibits</div>

    <div><br />
    </div>

    <div>
      <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" id="z03f1f3da240d4adf90b2f385347c81dd" style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; width: 100%;">


  <tr>

    <td style="width: 15%;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif;">Exhibit Number</span><span style="text-indent: 0px; font-size: 5.14pt;"><br />
              </span></td>

<body bgcolor="#ffffff" style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; color: #000000;">
  <div style="text-align: right;"><font style="font-weight: bold;">Exhibit 99.1</font><br>
  </div>
  <div> <br>
  </div>
  <div>
    <div class="bw-release">
      <h1> <b>Newmont Announces Record Third Quarter 2020 Results</b> </h1>
      <div class="bw-release-subhead">
        <p><b> Newmont delivers significant value in Q3 with right-sized portfolio of world-class assets; momentum into 2021 </b></p>
      </div>
      <div class="bw-release-body">
        <div class="bw-release-table-js bw-release-story">
          <p>DENVER--(BUSINESS WIRE)--October 29, 2020--Newmont Corporation (NYSE: NEM, TSX: NGT) (Newmont or the Company) today announced third quarter 2020 results. </p>
          <p> <b>THIRD QUARTER 2020 HIGHLIGHTS</b> </p>
          <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
            <li> Produced 1.5 million attributable ounces of gold<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">*</sup> and reported CAS<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">*</sup> of $756 per ounce and AISC<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">*</sup> of $1,020 per ounce and produced 273 thousand attributable gold equivalent ounces from co-products </li>
            <li> Generated $1.6 billion of cash from continuing operations and $1.3 billion of Free Cash Flow<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">*</sup> </li>
            <li> Reported $4.8 billion of consolidated cash with $7.8 billion of liquidity and a net debt to adjusted EBITDA<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">*</sup> ratio of 0.4x </li>
            <li> All sites operational with wide-ranging controls and safety protocols continuing to manage the Covid pandemic while placing the health, safety and wellbeing of our people and communities above all else </li>
            <li> On track to finish 2020 strong and meet full-year guidance </li>
            <li> Declared third quarter dividend of $0.40 per share, an increase of 60 percent over the prior quarter </li>
            <li> Formed exploration joint ventures with Agnico Eagle Mines Limited in Colombia and Kirkland Lake Gold Inc. in Canada </li>
            <li> Announced sale of royalty portfolio to Maverix Metals for total consideration of approximately $90 million </li>
            <li> Achieved gender parity amongst independent non-executive Board Directors </li>
          </ul>
          <p> &#8220;Capitalizing on the strength of our portfolio and higher gold prices, we delivered record third quarter adjusted EBITDA of $1.7 billion and free cash flow of $1.3 billion. This was the best quarterly financial performance in Newmont&#8217;s
            history. We also remain focused above all else on protecting the health, safety and wellbeing of our workforce and neighboring communities as the pandemic continues," said Tom Palmer, President and Chief Executive Officer. "As demonstrated by
            our second dividend increase this year, with a 79 percent increase in January and a further 60 percent increase in October, I am confident that our world-class portfolio is best positioned to generate industry-leading value and returns for our
            shareholders." </p>
          <p> <b>- Tom Palmer, President and Chief Executive Officer</b> </p>
          <p> <b>QUARTERLY DIVIDEND INCREASED 60 PERCENT</b> </p>
          <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
            <li> Annualized dividend of $1.60 per share is highest in the gold sector<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">** </sup> </li>
            <li> Announced dividend framework that maintains leading $1.00 per share sustainable base dividend and provides additional returns from Newmont&#8217;s significant free cash flow generation at higher gold prices </li>
            <li> Strong financial position and world-class portfolio supports a higher dividend as we continue to progress our most profitable projects </li>
            <li> Industry-leading dividend yield of 2.7% exceeds median of S&amp;P 500 Index </li>
            <li> During 2019 and 2020, we will have returned more than $2.5B to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks </li>
          </ul>
          <p> <i>___________________________</i> </p>
          <p> <i>*See footnotes provided below, as well as the cautionary statement at end of release regarding forward-looking statements, including with respect to financial and operating outlook and expected returns to shareholders.</i> </p>
          <p> <i>**An annualized dividend has not been declared by the Board. The above represents management&#8217;s expectations based upon the increased level declared for the third quarter. The declaration of future quarterly dividends remains at the
              discretion of the Board. Investors are cautioned that the Company&#8217;s dividend framework and the expected annualized dividend level are non-binding. See the cautionary statement at the end of this release.</i> </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">

          </div>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z06acd8ee0bdc4a8db4cfcb22b3375b7c" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

                </td>

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">

                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> $ </p>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;">
                  <p style="text-align: right; list-style-position: inside;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> 1,301 </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> &#160; </p>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">

                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> $ </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;">
                  <p style="text-align: right; list-style-position: inside;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> 611 </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> &#160; </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> $ </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;padding-right: 0px;">
                  <p style="text-align: right; list-style-position: inside;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> 365 </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> &#160; </p>
                </td>

          </table>
          <p> <b>Attributable gold production<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">1</sup></b> decreased 6 percent to 1,541 thousand ounces from the prior year quarter primarily due to ongoing Covid-related impacts at Yanacocha, Cerro Negro and &#201;l&#233;onore as the operations continued to
            ramp up in the third quarter from care and maintenance, in addition to the sale of Red Lake and Kalgoorlie, partially offset by higher production at Pe&#241;asquito and Musselwhite. </p>
          <p> <b>Gold CAS<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">2</sup></b> decreased 8 percent to $1,130 million from the prior year quarter primarily due to lower gold ounces sold. Gold CAS per ounce increased 3 percent to $756 per ounce primarily due to higher stripping ratios at
            Yanacocha, Merian, Akyem, lower surface grades at Ahafo and higher gold price-related royalties. </p>
          <p> <b>Gold AISC<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">3</sup></b> increased 3 percent to $1,020 per ounce from the prior year quarter primarily due to higher CAS per ounce and Covid-related care and maintenance costs, partially offset by lower sustaining capital spend. </p>
          <p> <b>Attributable gold equivalent ounce (GEO) production from other metals </b>increased 16 percent to 273 thousand ounces primarily due to operations at Pe&#241;asquito receiving sustained community support compared to the prior year blockade and
            higher recoveries at Boddington. <b>CAS from other metals</b> totaled $139 million for the quarter. <b>CAS per GEO<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">2</sup></b> improved 26 percent to $556 per ounce from the prior year quarter primarily due to higher sales at Pe&#241;asquito,
            partially offset by foreign exchange impacts in Australia and lower sales at Boddington. <b>AISC per GEO<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">3</sup></b> improved 33 percent to $770 per ounce primarily due to lower CAS from other metals and lower sustaining capital spend. </p>
          <p> <b>Net income</b> from continuing operations attributable to Newmont stockholders was $611 million or $0.76 per diluted share, a decrease of $1,615 million from the prior year quarter primarily due to the recognized gain on the formation of
            Nevada Gold Mines (NGM) in the prior year, lower sales volumes due to the sale of Kalgoorlie and Red Lake, higher costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and pension settlement charges, partially offset by higher average realized gold prices
            and lower tax expense, exploration costs, Goldcorp transaction costs and general and administrative costs. </p>
          <p> <b>Adjusted net income<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">4</sup> </b>was $697 million or $0.86 per diluted share,<b> </b>compared to $292 million or $0.36 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. The adjustments to net income of $0.10 primarily related to pension
            settlements, changes in the fair value of investments, COVID-19 specific costs, asset impairments, restructuring and severance costs, settlement costs including the costs from the Cedros community agreement at Pe&#241;asquito, valuation allowance
            and other tax adjustments. <b>Adjusted EBITDA<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">5</sup></b> improved 54 percent to $1,663 million for the quarter, compared to $1,079 million for the prior year quarter. </p>
          <p> <b>Revenue </b>increased<b> </b>17 percent from the prior year quarter to $3,170 million primarily due to higher average realized gold prices, partially offset by lower gold sales volumes. </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> <b>Average realized price<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">6</sup></b> for gold was $1,913, an increase of $437 per ounce over the prior year quarter; average realized price for copper was $2.99, an increase of $0.62 per pound over the prior year quarter; average
            realized price for silver was $21.69 per ounce, an increase of $4.51 per ounce over the prior year quarter; average realized price for lead was $0.73 per pound, a decrease of $0.11 per pound; average realized price for zinc was $1.01 per pound,
            an increase of $0.20 per pound over the prior year quarter. </p>
          <p> <b>Capital expenditures<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">7</sup></b> decreased 31 percent from the prior year quarter to $296 million, primarily due to the sale of Red Lake and Kalgoorlie and reduced spending from the completion of Borden Underground, Ahafo Mill
            Expansion, and other sustaining projects in 2019. Development capital expenditures in 2020 primarily include advancing Tanami Expansion 2, Yanacocha Sulfides, Ahafo North, the Subika mining method change, Musselwhite Materials Handling System,
            &#201;l&#233;onore Lower Mine Material Handling System, Quecher Main, and projects associated with the Company&#8217;s ownership interest in Nevada Gold Mines. </p>
          <p> <b>Consolidated operating cash flow from continuing operations </b>increased 101 percent from the prior year quarter to $1,597 million due to higher realized gold prices, partially offset by lower sales volumes.<b> Free Cash Flow<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">8</sup>
            </b>also<b> </b>increased to $1,301 million primarily due to higher operating cash flow and lower capital expenditures. </p>
          <p> <b>Balance sheet </b>ended the quarter with $4.8 billion of consolidated cash and approximately $7.8 billion of liquidity; reported net debt to adjusted EBITDA of 0.4x<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">9</sup>. </p>
          <p> <b>Nevada Gold Mines (NGM) </b>attributable gold production was 337 thousand ounces with CAS of $761 per ounce and AISC of $904 per ounce for the third quarter of 2020. EBITDA for NGM was $374 million. </p>
          <p> <b>Pueblo Viejo (PV) </b>attributable gold production was 87 thousand ounces. Pueblo Viejo EBITDA<sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">10</sup> was $115 million and cash distributions received for the Company's equity method investment totaled $75 million in the third
            quarter. </p>
          <p> <b>COVID-19 UPDATE</b> </p>
          <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
            <li> Continued our wide-ranging controls at the Company's operations and offices to put the health, safety, and overall wellbeing of Newmont's people and communities above all else </li>
            <li> Maintained effective testing, quarantine and contact tracing procedures for positive cases </li>
            <li> Incurred $35 million of care and maintenance costs during the third quarter, which included wages, direct operating costs for critical activities and non-cash depreciation for sites ramping up from care and maintenance or continuing to
              operate at reduced levels </li>
            <li> Incurred $32 million of incremental Covid specific costs for activities such as additional health and safety procedures, increased transportation and community fund contributions </li>
            <li> Distributed $9 million to date from Newmont's $20 million Global Community Support Fund focused on employee and community health, food security and local economic resilience through partnerships with local governments, medical
              institutions, charities and non-governmental organizations </li>
          </ul>
          <p> <b>PROJECTS UPDATE</b> </p>
          <p> Newmont&#8217;s capital-efficient project pipeline supports stable production with improving margins and mine life. Funding for the current development capital projects Tanami Expansion 2 and Musselwhite Materials Handling has been approved and the
            projects are in execution. Additional projects not listed below represent incremental improvements to the Company's outlook. </p>
          <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
            <li> <u>Tanami Expansion 2</u> (Australia) secures Tanami&#8217;s future as a long-life, low cost producer with potential to extend mine life to 2040 through the addition of a 1,460 meter hoisting shaft and supporting
              infrastructure to achieve 3.5 million tonnes per year of production and provide a platform for future growth. The expansion is expected to increase average annual gold production by approximately 150,000 to 200,000 ounces per year for the
              first five years beginning in 2023, and is expected to reduce operating costs by approximately 10 percent. Capital costs for the project are estimated to be between $700 million and $800 million. </li>
          </ul>
          <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
            <li> <u>Musselwhite Materials Handling</u> (North America) improves material movement from Musselwhite&#8217;s two main zones below Lake Opapimiskan. An underground shaft will hoist ore from the underground crushers, reducing
              haulage distances and ventilation costs. The project is 95 percent complete; however, full commissioning has been delayed amidst the Covid pandemic as Musselwhite operations were previously on care and maintenance. The Company expects to
              commission the project upon completion of the Musselwhite conveyor system by the end of 2020.
              <p> &#160; </p>
            </li>
          </ul>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> <b>OUTLOOK</b> </p>
          <p> Newmont's 2020 attributable gold production is unchanged at approximately 6.0 million ounces and the Company expects to produce approximately 1.0 million gold equivalent ounces from co-products. Gold CAS is expected to be $760 per ounce, and
            gold AISC is expected to be $1,015 per ounce. </p>
          <p> Newmont's capital expenditure for 2020 is expected to be approximately $1.4 billion as the Company continues to progress the majority of its development and sustaining capital projects, including Tanami Expansion 2, developing the sub-level
            shrinkage mining method at Subika Underground and advancing laybacks at Boddington and Ahafo. </p>
          <p> For exploration and advanced projects, approximately 80 percent of the Company&#8217;s exploration budget is allocated to near-mine activities. Newmont's 2020 exploration and advanced project spend is expected to be approximately $350 million as
            the majority of infill drilling programs and Greenfield exploration actives have resumed with the lifting of Covid restrictions globally. Advanced project study work for Yanacocha Sulfides and Ahafo North continues remotely. </p>
          <p> Newmont continues to maintain wide-ranging protective measures for its workforce and neighboring communities, including screening, physical distancing, deep cleaning, and avoiding exposure for at-risk individuals. If at any point the Company
            determines that continuing operations poses an increased risk to our workforce or host communities, it will reduce operational activities up to and including care and maintenance and management of critical environmental systems. Newmont&#8217;s 2020
            outlook assumes operations continue throughout the remainder of the year without major Covid-related interruptions. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">1</sup> <i>Attributable gold production for the third quarter 2020 includes 87 thousand ounces from the Company&#8217;s equity method investment in Pueblo Viejo (40%).</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">2</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Costs applicable to sales.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">3</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Costs applicable to sales.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">4</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Net income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">5</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Net income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">6</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Sales.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">7</sup> <i>Capital expenditures refers to Additions to property plant and mine development from the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">8</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation to Net cash provided by operating activities.</i> </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">9</sup> <i>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation.</i> </p>
          <p> <i><sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">10 </sup>Non-GAAP measure. See end of this release for reconciliation.</i> </p>

          </table>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">a</sup> 2020 outlook projections used in this presentation are considered forward-looking statements and represent management&#8217;s good faith estimates or expectations of future production results as of October 29, 2020. Outlook is based
            upon certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, metal prices, oil prices, certain exchange rates and other assumptions. For example, 2020 Outlook assumes $1,200/oz gold, $16/oz silver, $2.75/lb copper, $1.20/lb zinc, $0.95/lb lead,
            $0.75 USD/AUD exchange rate, $0.77 USD/CAD exchange rate and $60/barrel WTI; AISC and CAS estimates do not include inflation, for the remainder of the year. Production, CAS, AISC and capital estimates exclude projects that have not yet been
            approved. The potential impact on inventory valuation as a result of lower prices, input costs, and project decisions are not included as part of this Outlook. Assumptions used for purposes of Outlook may prove to be incorrect and actual
            results may differ from those anticipated, including variation beyond a +/-5% range. Outlook cannot be guaranteed. As such, investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance upon Outlook and forward-looking statements as there can be no
            assurance that the plans, assumptions or expectations upon which they are placed will occur. Amounts may not recalculate to totals due to rounding. See cautionary at the end of this release. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">b</sup> All-in sustaining costs or AISC as used in the Company&#8217;s Outlook is a non-GAAP metric; see below for further information and reconciliation to consolidated 2020 CAS outlook. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">c</sup> Represents the ownership interest in the Nevada Gold Mines (NGM) joint venture. NGM is owned 38.5% by Newmont and owned 61.5% and operated by Barrick. The Company accounts for its interest in NGM using the proportionate
            consolidation method, thereby recognizing its pro-rata share of the assets, liabilities and operations of NGM. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">d</sup> Attributable gold production outlook includes the Company&#8217;s equity investment (40%) in Pueblo Viejo with ~375Koz in 2020; does not include the Company&#8217;s other equity investments. Attributable gold production outlook represents
            the Company's 51.35% interest for Yanacocha and a 75% interest for Merian. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">e </sup>Gold equivalent ounces (GEO) is calculated as pounds or ounces produced multiplied by the ratio of the other metal&#8217;s price to the gold price, using Gold ($1,200/oz.), Copper ($2.75/lb.), Silver ($16/oz.), Lead ($0.95/lb.), and
            Zinc ($1.20/lb.) pricing. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">f</sup> The adjusted tax rate excludes certain items such as tax valuation allowance adjustments. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">g</sup> Assuming average prices of $1,400 per ounce for gold, $16 per ounce for silver, $2.75 per pound for copper, $0.95 per pound for lead, and $1.20 per pound for zinc and achievement of current production and sales volumes and cost
            estimates, we estimate our consolidated adjusted effective tax rate related to continuing operations for 2020 will be between 38%-42%. </p>

          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(3)</sup> Newmont contributed its existing Nevada mining operations in exchange for a 38.5% interest in NGM, effective July 1, 2019. </p>
          <p> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(4)</sup> Represents attributable gold from Pueblo Viejo and does not include the Company's other equity method investments. Attributable gold ounces produced at Pueblo Viejo are not included in attributable gold ounces sold, as noted
            in footnote 1. Income and expenses of equity method investments are included in <i>Equity income (loss) of affiliates.</i> </p>

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;"><sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(1)</sup></td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <i>Acquisitions, net </i>for the three months ended September 30, 2019 is comprised of $&#8212; cash and cash equivalents acquired, net of $&#8212; cash paid to Goldcorp shareholders, in the Newmont
                    Goldcorp transaction and $6 of restricted cash acquired in the formation of Nevada Gold Mines. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;"><sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(2)</sup></td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <i>Acquisitions, net </i>for the nine months ended September 30, 2019 is comprised of $138 cash and cash equivalents acquired, net of $17 cash paid to Goldcorp shareholders, in the
                    Newmont Goldcorp transaction and $6 of restricted cash acquired in the formation of Nevada Gold Mines. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

          </table>

          </div>
          <p> <b>Non-GAAP Financial Measures </b> </p>
          <p> Non-GAAP financial measures are intended to provide additional information only and do not have any standard meaning prescribed by U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&#8220;GAAP&#8221;). These measures should not be considered in isolation or
            as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. Unless otherwise noted, we present the Non-GAAP financial measures of our continuing operations in the tables below. For additional information regarding our
            discontinued operations, see Note 13 to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements. </p>
          <p> <b><i>Adjusted net income (loss)</i></b> </p>
          <p> Management uses Adjusted net income (loss) to evaluate the Company&#8217;s operating performance and for planning and forecasting future business operations. The Company believes the use of Adjusted net income (loss) allows investors and analysts
            to understand the results of the continuing operations of the Company and its direct and indirect subsidiaries relating to the sale of products, by excluding certain items that have a disproportionate impact on our results for a particular
            period. Adjustments to continuing operations are presented before tax and net of our partners&#8217; noncontrolling interests, when applicable. The tax effect of adjustments is presented in the Tax effect of adjustments line and is calculated using
            the applicable regional tax rate. Management&#8217;s determination of the components of Adjusted net income (loss) are evaluated periodically and based, in part, on a review of non-GAAP financial measures used by mining industry analysts. <i>Net
              income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders</i> is reconciled to Adjusted net income (loss) as follows: </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z929a51283a384d218b8cd92dbcb14d6c" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Pension settlements, included in <i>Other income, net,</i> represents pension settlement charges in 2020. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(7)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Loss on debt extinguishment, included in <i>Other income, net,</i> primarily represents losses on the extinguishment of a portion of the 2022 Senior Notes and 2023 Senior Notes during
                    March and April 2020. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(8)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> COVID-19 specific costs, net, included in <i>Other expense, net</i>, represents incremental direct costs incurred as a result of actions taken to protect against the impacts of the
                    COVID-19 pandemic. Amounts are presented net of income (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $(5) and $(5), respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(9)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Settlement costs, net, included in <i>Other expense, net</i>, primarily represents costs related to the Cedros community agreement at Penasquito in Mexico, a water related settlement at
                    Yanacocha in Peru, mineral interest settlements at Ahafo and Akyem in Africa and other related costs. Amounts are presented net of income (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $(3) and $(3), respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(10)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Impairment of long-lived and other assets, included in <i>Other expense, net</i>, represents non-cash write-downs of long-lived assets and materials and supplies inventories. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(11)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Goldcorp transaction and integration costs, included in <i>Other expense, net</i>, primarily represents costs incurred related to the Newmont Goldcorp transaction completed during 2019 as
                    well as subsequent integration costs. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(12)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Restructuring and severance, net, included in <i>Other expense, net</i>, primarily represents severance and related costs associated with significant organizational or operating model
                    changes implemented by the Company. Amounts are presented net of income (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $&#8212; and $(1), respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(13)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> The tax effect of adjustments, included in <i>Income and mining tax benefit (expense)</i>, represents the tax effect of adjustments in footnotes (3) through (12), as described above, and
                    are calculated using the applicable regional tax rate. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(14)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Valuation allowance and other tax adjustments, net, included in <i>Income and mining tax benefit (expense)</i>, is recorded for items such as foreign tax credits, alternative minimum tax
                    credits, capital losses, disallowed foreign losses, and the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates on deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities. The adjustment for the three and nine months ended September 30, 2020
                    is due to a net increase or (decrease) to net operating losses, tax credit carryovers and other deferred tax assets subject to valuation allowance of $7 and $(113), respectively, the effects of changes in foreign exchange rates on
                    deferred tax assets and liabilities of $14 and $(173), respectively, changes to the reserve for uncertain tax positions of $(10) and $(19), respectively, and other tax adjustments of $3 and $35, respectively. Total amount is presented
                    net of income (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $(4) and $(26), respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(15)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Adjusted net income (loss) has not been adjusted for $25 and $158 of cash and $9 and $83 of non-cash care and maintenance costs, included in <i>Care and maintenance </i>and <i>Depreciation
                      and amortization</i>, respectively, which primarily represent costs associated with our Musselwhite, &#201;l&#233;onore, Pe&#241;asquito, Yanacocha and Cerro Negro sites being temporarily placed into care and maintenance in response to the COVID-19
                    pandemic during a portion of the three and nine months ended September 30, 2020, respectively. Amounts are presented net of income (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $1, $13, $&#8212; and $3, respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(16)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Adjusted net income (loss) per diluted share is calculated using diluted common shares, which are calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

                </td>

                    attributable to noncontrolling interests of $(1) and $(1), respectively. </p>

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(12)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Settlement costs, included in <i>Other expense, net,</i> primarily represents certain costs associated with legal and other settlements. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(13)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Impairment of investments, included in <i>Other income, net</i>, represents other-than-temporary impairments of other investments. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(14)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> The tax effect of adjustments, included in Income and mining tax benefit (expense), represents the tax effect of adjustments in footnotes (3) through (13), as described above, and are
                    calculated using the applicable regional tax rate. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(15)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Valuation allowance and other tax adjustments, included in <i>Income and mining tax benefit (expense)</i>, is recorded for items such as foreign tax credits, alternative minimum tax
                    credits, capital losses, disallowed foreign losses, and the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates on deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities. The adjustment in the three and nine months ended September 30, 2019
                    is due to increases or (decreases) to net operating losses, tax credit carryovers and other deferred tax assets subject to valuation allowance of $87 and $111 respectively, the effects of changes in foreign exchange rates on deferred
                    tax assets and liabilities of $(147) and $(150), respectively, additions to the reserve for uncertain tax positions of $7 and $21, respectively and other tax adjustments of $8 and $5, respectively. Amounts are presented net of income
                    (loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests of $(3) and $(2), respectively. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(16)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Adjusted net income (loss) per diluted share is calculated using diluted common shares, which are calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation and amortization and Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation and amortization</i></b> </p>
          <p> Management uses Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation and amortization (&#8220;EBITDA&#8221;) and EBITDA adjusted for non-core or certain items that have a disproportionate impact on our results for a particular period (&#8220;Adjusted EBITDA&#8221;) as
            non-GAAP measures to evaluate the Company&#8217;s operating performance. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA do not represent, and should not be considered an alternative to, net income (loss), operating income (loss), or cash flow from operations as those
            terms are defined by GAAP, and do not necessarily indicate whether cash flows will be sufficient to fund cash needs. Although Adjusted EBITDA and similar measures are frequently used as measures of operations and the ability to meet debt
            service requirements by other companies, our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA is not necessarily comparable to such other similarly titled captions of other companies. The Company believes that Adjusted EBITDA provides useful information to
            investors and others in understanding and evaluating our operating results in the same manner as our management and Board of Directors. Management&#8217;s determination of the components of Adjusted EBITDA are evaluated periodically and based, in
            part, on a review of non-GAAP financial measures used by mining industry analysts. Net income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders is reconciled to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as follows: </p>
          <div> </div>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> (Gain) loss on asset and investment sales, included in <i>Gain on asset and investment sales, net</i>, primarily represents a $493 gain on the sale of Kalgoorlie in January 2020, a $91
                    gain on the sale of Continental and a $9 gain on the sale of Red Lake in March 2020 and represents a gain on the sale of exploration land in 2019. For additional information, see Note 9 to our Condensed Consolidated Financial
                    Statements. </p>

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(3)</sup> </p>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1"><br>
                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Change in fair value of investments, included in <i>Other income, net,</i> primarily represents unrealized holding gains and losses on marketable equity securities and our investment
                    instruments. For additional information regarding our investments, see Note 19 to our Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>
              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">

                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Impairment of investments, included in <i>Other income, net,</i> primarily represents the other-than-temporary impairment of the TMAC investment recorded in March 2020. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">

                    March and April 2020. </p>

              </tr>

                    pandemic. </p>

                    Yanacocha in Peru, mineral interest settlements at Ahafo and Akyem in Africa and other related costs, and certain costs associated with legal and other settlements for 2019. </p>
                </td>

                    implemented by the Company for all periods presented. </p>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">

                    including adjustments related to a review of the project cost estimates at the Dawn remediation site, as well as increased water management costs at the Con Mine. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

                    carrying value of the Nevada mining operations contributed. </p>

                    our Musselwhite, &#201;l&#233;onore, Pe&#241;asquito, Yanacocha and Cerro Negro mine sites being temporarily placed into care and maintenance in response to the COVID-19 pandemic during a portion of the three and nine months ended September 30, 2020,
                    respectively. </p>

          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> Additionally, the Company uses Pueblo Viejo EBITDA as a non-GAAP measure to evaluate the operating performance of its investment in the Pueblo Viejo mine. Pueblo Viejo EBITDA does not represent, and should not be considered an alternative to,
            Equity income (loss) of affiliates, as defined by GAAP, and does not necessarily indicate whether cash distributions from Pueblo Viejo will match Pueblo Viejo EBITDA or earnings from affiliates. Although the Company has the ability to exert
            significant influence, it does not have direct control over the operations or resulting revenues and expenses, nor does it proportionately consolidate its investment in Pueblo Viejo. The Company believes that Pueblo Viejo EBITDA provides useful
            information to investors and others in understanding and evaluating the operating results of its investment in Pueblo Viejo, in the same manner as management and the Board of Directors. Equity income (loss) of affiliates is reconciled to Pueblo
            Viejo EBITDA as follows:&#8203; </p>

          </table>
          <p> The Company uses NGM EBITDA as a non-GAAP measure to evaluate the operating performance of its investment in Nevada Gold Mines (NGM). NGM EBITDA does not represent, and should not be considered an alternative to, Income (loss) before income
            and mining tax and other items, as defined by GAAP, and does not necessarily indicate whether cash distributions from NGM will match NGM EBITDA. Although the Company has the ability to exert significant influence and proportionally consolidates
            its 38.5% interest in NGM, it does not have direct control over the operations or resulting revenues and expenses of its investment in NGM. The Company believes that NGM EBITDA provides useful information to investors and others in
            understanding and evaluating the operating results of its investment in NGM, in the same manner as management and the Board of Directors. Income (loss) before income and mining tax and other items is reconciled to NGM EBITDA as follows: </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z39daae755b11409f85d6ffae57b8ee95" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

              </tr>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>Free Cash Flow</i></b> </p>
          <p> Management uses Free Cash Flow as a non-GAAP measure to analyze cash flows generated from operations. Free Cash Flow is <i>Net cash provided by (used in) operating activities</i> less <i>Net cash provided by (used in) operating activities
              of discontinued operations</i> less <i>Additions to property, plant and mine development</i> as presented on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows. The Company believes Free Cash Flow is also useful as one of the bases for
            comparing the Company&#8217;s performance with its competitors. Although Free Cash Flow and similar measures are frequently used as measures of cash flows generated from operations by other companies, the Company&#8217;s calculation of Free Cash Flow is
            not necessarily comparable to such other similarly titled captions of other companies. </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> The presentation of non-GAAP Free Cash Flow is not meant to be considered in isolation or as an alternative to net income as an indicator of the Company&#8217;s performance, or as an alternative to cash flows from operating activities as a measure
            of liquidity as those terms are defined by GAAP, and does not necessarily indicate whether cash flows will be sufficient to fund cash needs. The Company&#8217;s definition of Free Cash Flow is limited in that it does not represent residual cash flows
            available for discretionary expenditures due to the fact that the measure does not deduct the payments required for debt service and other contractual obligations or payments made for business acquisitions. Therefore, the Company believes it is
            important to view Free Cash Flow as a measure that provides supplemental information to the Company&#8217;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows. </p>
          <p> The following table sets forth a reconciliation of Free Cash Flow, a non-GAAP financial measure, to <i>Net cash provided by (used in) operating activities</i>, which the Company believes to be the GAAP financial measure most directly
            comparable to Free Cash Flow, as well as information regarding <i>Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities</i> and <i>Net cash provided by (used in) financing activities.</i> </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z8763382b1b524bd0b2bce84d20201e16" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

              <tr>

                </td>

                    Flow.&#8203; </p>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>Costs applicable to sales per ounce/gold equivalent ounce </i></b> </p>
          <p> Costs applicable to sales per ounce/gold equivalent ounce are non-GAAP financial measures. These measures are calculated by dividing the costs applicable to sales of gold and other metals by gold ounces or gold equivalent ounces sold,
            respectively. These measures are calculated for the periods presented on a consolidated basis. Costs applicable to sales per ounce/gold equivalent ounce statistics are intended to provide additional information only and do not have any
            standardized meaning prescribed by GAAP and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. The measures are not necessarily indicative of operating profit or cash flow from
            operations as determined under GAAP. Other companies may calculate these measures differently. </p>
          <p> The following tables reconcile these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures. </p>
          <p> <b><i>Costs applicable to sales per ounce</i></b> </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z127bd87f734049cf939400c208baa716" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

                    $16/oz.), Lead ($0.95/lb.) and Zinc ($1.20/lb.) pricing for 2020 and Gold ($1,200/oz.), Copper ($2.75/lb.), Silver ($15/oz.), Lead ($0.90/lb.) and Zinc ($1.05/lb.) pricing for 2019. </p>

          <table cellspacing="0" id="z5fd705fc0c614dadadba856763c85034" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(1)</sup> </p>

              <tr>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(3)</sup> </p>

                </td>
                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Per ounce measures may not recalculate due to rounding. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>All-In Sustaining Costs </i></b> </p>
          <p> Newmont has developed a metric that expands on GAAP measures, such as cost of goods sold, and non-GAAP measures, such as costs applicable to sales per ounce, to provide visibility into the economics of our mining operations related to
            expenditures, operating performance and the ability to generate cash flow from our continuing operations. </p>
          <p> Current GAAP measures used in the mining industry, such as cost of goods sold, do not capture all of the expenditures incurred to discover, develop and sustain production. Therefore, we believe that all-in sustaining costs is a non-GAAP
            measure that provides additional information to management, investors and analysts that aid in the understanding of the economics of our operations and performance compared to other producers and provides investors visibility by better defining
            the total costs associated with production. </p>
          <p> All-in sustaining cost (&#8220;AISC&#8221;) amounts are intended to provide additional information only and do not have any standardized meaning prescribed by GAAP and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance
            prepared in accordance with GAAP. The measures are not necessarily indicative of operating profit or cash flow from operations as determined under GAAP. Other companies may calculate these measures differently as a result of differences in the
            underlying accounting principles, policies applied and in accounting frameworks such as in International Financial Reporting Standards (&#8220;IFRS&#8221;), or by reflecting the benefit from selling non-gold metals as a reduction to AISC. Differences may
            also arise related to definitional differences of sustaining versus development (i.e. non-sustaining) activities based upon each company&#8217;s internal policies. </p>
          <p> The following disclosure provides information regarding the adjustments made in determining the all-in sustaining costs measure: </p>
          <p> <i>Costs applicable to sales</i>. Includes all direct and indirect costs related to current production incurred to execute the current mine plan. We exclude certain exceptional or unusual amounts from <i>Costs applicable to sales </i>(&#8220;CAS&#8221;),
            such as significant revisions to recovery amounts. CAS includes by-product credits from certain metals obtained during the process of extracting and processing the primary ore-body. CAS is accounted for on an accrual basis and excludes <i>Depreciation
              and amortization</i> and <i>Reclamation and remediation</i>, which is consistent with our presentation of CAS on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. In determining AISC, only the CAS associated with producing and selling an
            ounce of gold is included in the measure. Therefore, the amount of gold CAS included in AISC is derived from the CAS presented in the Company&#8217;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations less the amount of CAS attributable to the
            production of other metals at our Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines. The other metals CAS at those mine sites is disclosed in Note 4 to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements. The allocation of CAS between gold and other metals
            at the Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines is based upon the relative sales value of gold and other metals produced during the period. </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> <i>Reclamation costs</i>. Includes accretion expense related to reclamation liabilities and the amortization of the related Asset Retirement Cost (&#8220;ARC&#8221;) for the Company&#8217;s operating properties. Accretion related to the reclamation
            liabilities and the amortization of the ARC assets for reclamation does not reflect annual cash outflows but are calculated in accordance with GAAP. The accretion and amortization reflect the periodic costs of reclamation associated with
            current production and are therefore included in the measure. The allocation of these costs to gold and other metals is determined using the same allocation used in the allocation of CAS between gold and other metals at the Pe&#241;asquito,
            Boddington, and Phoenix mines. </p>
          <p> <i>Advanced projects, research and development and exploration</i>. Includes incurred expenses related to projects that are designed to sustain current production and exploration. We note that as current resources are depleted, exploration
            and advanced projects are necessary for us to replace the depleting reserves or enhance the recovery and processing of the current reserves to sustain production at existing operations. As these costs relate to sustaining our production, and
            are considered a continuing cost of a mining company, these costs are included in the AISC measure. These costs are derived from the <i>Advanced projects, research and development</i> and <i>Exploration</i> amounts presented in the Condensed
            Consolidated Statements of Operations less incurred expenses related to the development of new operations, or related to major projects at existing operations where these projects will materially benefit the operation in the future. The
            allocation of these costs to gold and other metals is determined using the same allocation used in the allocation of CAS between gold and other metals at the Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines. </p>
          <p> <i>General and administrative</i>. Includes costs related to administrative tasks not directly related to current production, but rather related to support our corporate structure and fulfill our obligations to operate as a public company.
            Including these expenses in the AISC metric provides visibility of the impact that general and administrative activities have on current operations and profitability on a per ounce basis. </p>
          <p> <i>Care and maintenance and Other expense, net</i>. <i>Care and maintenance</i> includes direct operating and development capital costs incurred at the mine sites during the period that these sites were temporarily placed into care and
            maintenance in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. For <i>Other expense, net</i> we exclude certain exceptional or unusual expenses, such as restructuring, as these are not indicative to sustaining our current operations. Furthermore, this
            adjustment to <i>Other expense, net</i> is also consistent with the nature of the adjustments made to <i>Net income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders</i> as disclosed in the Company&#8217;s non-GAAP financial measure Adjusted net income
            (loss). The allocation of these costs to gold and other metals is determined using the same allocation used in the allocation of CAS between gold and other metals at the Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines. </p>
          <p> <i>Treatment and refining costs</i>. Includes costs paid to smelters for treatment and refining of our concentrates to produce the salable metal. These costs are presented net as a reduction of <i>Sales</i> on our Condensed Consolidated
            Statements of Operations. The allocation of these costs to gold and other metals is determined using the same allocation used in the allocation of CAS between gold and other metals at the Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines. </p>
          <p> <i>Sustaining capital and finance lease payments</i>. We determined sustaining capital and finance lease payments as those capital expenditures and finance lease payments that are necessary to maintain current production and execute the
            current mine plan. We determined development (i.e. non-sustaining) capital expenditures and finance lease payments to be those payments used to develop new operations or related to projects at existing operations where those projects will
            materially benefit the operation and are excluded from the calculation of AISC. The classification of sustaining and development capital projects and finance leases is based on a systematic review of our project portfolio in light of the nature
            of each project. Sustaining capital and finance lease payments are relevant to the AISC metric as these are needed to maintain the Company&#8217;s current operations and provide improved transparency related to our ability to finance these
            expenditures from current operations. The allocation of these costs to gold and other metals is determined using the same allocation used in the allocation of CAS between gold and other metals at the Pe&#241;asquito, Boddington, and Phoenix mines. </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="zc19b0db799d4430c82a699c9f5539b07" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

                    forward-looking All-in sustaining costs per ounce are independently calculated and, as a result, the total All-in sustaining costs and the All-in sustaining costs per ounce may not sum to the component ranges. While a reconciliation to
                    the most directly comparable GAAP measure has been provided for 2020 AISC Gold and Co-Product Outlook on a consolidated basis, a reconciliation has not been provided on an individual site or project basis in reliance on Item
                    10(e)(1)(i)(B) of Regulation S-K because such reconciliation is not available without unreasonable efforts. </p>

                </td>
              </tr>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>Net debt to Adjusted EBITDA ratio</i></b> </p>
          <p> Management uses net debt to Adjusted EBITDA as non-GAAP measures to evaluate the Company&#8217;s operating performance, including our ability to generate earnings sufficient to service our debt. Net debt to Adjusted EBITDA represents the ratio of
            the Company&#8217;s debt, net of cash and cash equivalents, to Adjusted EBITDA. Net debt to Adjusted EBITDA does not represent, and should not be considered an alternative to, net income (loss), operating income (loss), or cash flow from operations
            as those terms are defined by GAAP, and does not necessarily indicate whether cash flows will be sufficient to fund cash needs. Although Net Debt to Adjusted EBITDA and similar measures are frequently used as measures of operations and the
            ability to meet debt service requirements by other companies, our calculation of net debt to Adjusted EBITDA measure is not necessarily comparable to such other similarly titled captions of other companies. The Company believes that net debt to
            Adjusted EBITDA provides useful information to investors and others in understanding and evaluating our operating results in the same manner as our management and Board of Directors. Management&#8217;s determination of the components of net debt to
            Adjusted EBITDA is evaluated periodically and based, in part, on a review of non-GAAP financial measures used by mining industry analysts. Net income (loss) attributable to Newmont stockholders is reconciled to Adjusted EBITDA as follows: </p>
          <div> </div>

          </table>
          <p> <b><i>Net average realized price per ounce/ pound</i></b> </p>
          <p> Average realized price per ounce/ pound are non-GAAP financial measures. The measures are calculated by dividing the net consolidated gold, copper, silver, lead and zinc sales by the consolidated gold ounces, copper pounds, silver ounces,
            lead pounds and zinc pounds sold, respectively. These measures are calculated on a consistent basis for the periods presented on a consolidated basis. Average realized price per ounce/ pound statistics are intended to provide additional
            information only, do not have any standardized meaning prescribed by GAAP and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. The measures are not necessarily indicative of
            operating profit or cash flow from operations as determined under GAAP. Other companies may calculate these measures differently. </p>
          <p> The following tables reconcile these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure: </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z1ca6648894f04586a511789b5b582cae" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">

              <tr>

                </td>
                <td rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: bottom;border-bottom: solid black 1pt;padding-left: 0px;text-align: center; list-style-position: inside;white-space: nowrap;" colspan="7">
                  <p style="text-align: center; list-style-position: inside;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <b>Three Months Ended </b><br>
                    <b>September 30,</b> </p>
                </td>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;">
                  <p style="text-align: left;margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> <sup style="vertical-align: text-top; line-height: 1; font-size: smaller;">(1)</sup> </p>

                  <p> &#160; </p>

                <td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="vertical-align: top;padding-left: 0px;">
                  <p style="margin-bottom: 0px; margin-top: 0px;"> Per ounce/pound measures may not recalculate due to rounding. </p>
                </td>
              </tr>

          </table>
          <p> &#8203;<b><i>Gold by-product metrics </i></b> </p>
          <p> Copper, sliver, lead and zinc are by-products often obtained during the process of extracting and processing the primary ore-body. In our GAAP Consolidated Financial Statements, the value of these by-products is recorded as a credit to our
            CAS and the value of the primary ore is recorded as Sales. In certain instances, copper, silver, lead and zinc are co-products, or a significant resource in the primary ore-body, and the revenue is recorded as Sales in our GAAP Consolidated
            Financial Statements. </p>
          <p> Gold by-product metrics are non-GAAP financial measures that serve as a basis for comparing the Company&#8217;s performance with certain competitors. As Newmont&#8217;s operations are primarily focused on gold production, &#8220;Gold by-product metrics&#8221; were
            developed to allow investors to view Sales, CAS per ounce and AISC per ounce calculations that classify all copper, silver, lead and zinc production as a by-product, even when copper, silver, lead or zinc is a significant resource in the
            primary ore-body. These metrics are calculated by subtracting copper, silver, lead and zinc sales recognized from Sales and including these amounts as offsets to CAS. </p>
          <div> </div>
          <div style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10pt; CLEAR: both; MARGIN-TOP: 10pt" id="DSPFPageBreakArea">
            <div style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always" id="DSPFPageBreak">
              <hr style="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0px; HEIGHT: 2px; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0px; WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0px; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: both; MARGIN: 4px 0px; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0px; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000"> </div>
          </div>
          <p> Gold by-product metrics are calculated on a consistent basis for the periods presented on a consolidated basis. These metrics are intended to provide supplemental information only, do not have any standardized meaning prescribed by GAAP and
            should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. Other companies may calculate these measures differently as a result of differences in the underlying accounting principles,
            policies applied and in accounting frameworks, such as in IFRS. </p>
          <p> The following tables reconcile these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures: </p>
          <table cellspacing="0" id="z686606b91a8444f3a3b0da02e1f26249" style="margin-bottom: 10px;margin-left: 0px; margin-right: auto; font-size: 10pt;">
